Award.AwardTitle: Stress Distributions Determined in Short T2 BioMaterials by MRI-based Finite Strain and Mathematical Modeling

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to use a combination of medical imaging and mathematical modeling to determine and characterize the mechanics of biomaterials. Medical imaging modalities, such as magnetic resonance imaging (MRI), can noninvasively visualize internal strains throughout the volume of materials and tissues. Mathematical modeling extends the strain data to determine spatially-dependent stresses and material properties. Studies conducted under this award will determine the extent to which rapid MRI techniques can characterize the mechanics of a broad range of biomaterials that, in particular, exhibit short spin-spin (T2) relaxation times and are challenging to image. Mathematical modeling will further be developed to relate strains and stresses through the incorporation of MRI data with mixture theory and nonlinear constitutive relations.

If successful, these studies would significantly advance the characterization of materials and enhance the design of novel bio-inspired materials. The knowledge gained from results would additionally enable the evaluation of tissue damage and degeneration, and the characterization of tissue remodeling and implanted biomaterial integration. Research will be disseminated through publications and presentations. Integrated education and outreach activities arise as a natural and creative outgrowth of mechanics studies, and are designed to provide an interactive and problem-solving approach toward learning. Undergraduate courses in tissue mechanics will be augmented with new imaging-based modules. Emphasizing education and outreach activities will promote higher education in science and engineering from an early age through interactions with the Indianapolis Children's Museum.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research team completed a comprehensive study that advanced imaging and modeling techniques to better understand biological tissues and materials. Knowledge of the internal stresses and strains is important to understand the physiological mechanical environment and in the design of repair and replacement of biomaterials. Biomaterial testing ex vivo provides important information about the fundamental mechanics of a tissue under controlled conditions. Importantly, to provide less invasive measures of mechanical behavior, imaging technologies have measured the deformation and strains of explanted biomaterials. In particular, a variety of MRI techniques have been used to visualize the mechanical behavior of biomaterials within a physiologically relevant loading environment. In spite of these advances, high precision measurements of the in situ displacements, strains, and stresses within short T2 materials, especially bone and ligaments, remain unknown. Our research specifically developed a novel displacement-encoded MRI technique that is capable of measuring per-pixel mechanics in a range of biomaterials, including those with short T2 constants. The proposed research is significant because it determined for the first time the internal strains and stresses in a broad range of biomaterials using novel magnetic resonance imaging technology and constitutive modeling. The proposed biomechanics technique assess biomaterials in physiologic mechanical environments, provide critical design criteria for functional tissue engineering, and allow for noninvasive evaluation of tissue regeneration or repair. Additionally, the ability to compute stresses based on noninvasively determined strains will allow for a more comprehensive approach to studying the mechanical function and failure of biomaterials. Moreover, research was disseminated through multiple peer review publications and conference proceedings. The research led to the training of four graduate students, and well over 50 undergraduate students through course and lab participation. Unique cell models were developed and displayed at the Children's Museum of Indianapolis, which enabled a direct transfer of benchside knowledge to the classroom targeting the education of children and young adults.
